 I didn't think much of the video, but I feel the need to once again clear up the blinkered misconceptions of yet another war lover:
 
 Why did we attack Iraq? Simple, standard geostrategic concerns:
 In November 2000 Iraq opened an oil market denominated in Euros and not US$, much as the Iranians are planning at the moment. While not a direct threat to the dollar in itself, if the market was successful (which it undoubtedly would be) and other countries follow suit, it would lead to central banks around the world dumping their dollar reserves in favour of the Euro and other currencies, forcing the US to massively increase interest rates or face hyperinflation.9/11 provided the US administration with an excuse to attack Iraq after Afganhistan (where, by the way, a major oil pipeline is being/has been built now that we have a significant military presence there). Immediately following the invasion, the Iraq oil market re-opened priced in dollars. The State Deparament even had plans to sell off Iraq's oil to US and British companies. The invasion is part of a wide-ranging plan to dominate the central Asian region which contains enormous energy resources; following the invasion of Afghanistan new military bases were acquired by the US in the central asian region, not long before the withdrawal in April 2003 of US forces from their traditional home, Saudi Arabia.
 The occupation of Iraq IS unequivocally about oil, but not in the simplistic sense that some opponents of the war often unfortunately believe. 
 
 The coming decade will see oil prices continue to rise as China, India and much of the third world continue to industrialise; demand will increase far faster than supply can keep up with. The issue of remaining oil reserves is irrelevant. The Bush administration has taken steps to attempt to be on top of the game when the energy crisis becomes a serious issue. 
 
 Iran is now the only country in the region that is not subservient in one way or another to Western interests, and we are fighting hard to maintain a grip on Iraq that seems to be slipping, and we are making threatening noises in Iran's direction. 
 
 Read this article on US interests in Iraq:Oil In Iraq: The Heart of the Crisis
 
 and this one on the 2002 National Security Strategy which sets out the new US doctine of "Full Spectrum Dominance":Dominance and its Dilemmas

 Religion is an ideology. It's the realm of ideas. And Christianity in particular is pretty easily defensible in that it is a religion that says that these acts are wrong and against Christ's teachings. So as I said, these acts were an abandonment of the religion, not carrying it out.

 
 
 You are splitting hairs here. If Some one, who is the leader of a religion, carries out the killing of people in the name of the religion using the religion as a bases for their acts then the religion is to blame in the first place.

I didn't think much of the video, but I feel the need to once again clear up the blinkered misconceptions of yet another war lover:
 
 Why did we attack Iraq? Simple, standard geostrategic concerns:
 In November 2000 Iraq opened an oil market denominated in Euros and not US$, much as the Iranians are planning at the moment. While not a direct threat to the dollar in itself, if the market was successful (which it undoubtedly would be) and other countries follow suit, it would lead to central banks around the world dumping their dollar reserves in favour of the Euro and other currencies, forcing the US to massively increase interest rates or face hyperinflation.9/11 provided the US administration with an excuse to attack Iraq after Afganhistan (where, by the way, a major oil pipeline is being/has been built now that we have a significant military presence there). Immediately following the invasion, the Iraq oil market re-opened priced in dollars. The State Deparament even had plans to sell off Iraq's oil to US and British companies. The invasion is part of a wide-ranging plan to dominate the central Asian region which contains enormous energy resources; following the invasion of Afghanistan new military bases were acquired by the US in the central asian region, not long before the withdrawal in April 2003 of US forces from their traditional home, Saudi Arabia.
 The occupation of Iraq IS unequivocally about oil, but not in the simplistic sense that some opponents of the war often unfortunately believe. 
 
 The coming decade will see oil prices continue to rise as China, India and much of the third world continue to industrialise; demand will increase far faster than supply can keep up with. The issue of remaining oil reserves is irrelevant. The Bush administration has taken steps to attempt to be on top of the game when the energy crisis becomes a serious issue. 
 
 Iran is now the only country in the region that is not subservient in one way or another to Western interests, and we are fighting hard to maintain a grip on Iraq that seems to be slipping, and we are making threatening noises in Iran's direction. 
 
 Read this article on US interests in Iraq:Oil In Iraq: The Heart of the Crisis
 
 and this one on the 2002 National Security Strategy which sets out the new US doctine of "Full Spectrum Dominance":Dominance and its Dilemmas

hahaha, it sounds like your screaming conspiracy theories here... 

 
 There's no conspiracy, all the information is readily available if you look for it, this is the way the world works, it's standard practice, not a shadowy conspiracy.
 
 
And what are you trying to suggest... by having military bases in the Asian region that they are going to.... what? Invade Asian? 

 
 No, the military bases are there to secure US dominance over areas containing large oilfields and/or major pipelines as insurance against any problems caused by the inevitable energy crisis. 
 These areas are right next door to Russia and China, and the US is just trying to make sure that oil supply remains under the aegis of the West. It's a logical stategy to counter a potential threat to superpower status.
 
 
There's no point in going to war for oil, it's not forth the death and the amount of money a war against terrorist costs.
